It has been asserted in this forum that a working definition of 'Christian' is one who follows the teachings of Jesus. I want to examine that claim closely in this thread. It is my contention that nearly no one follows his teachings and, as a whole, the morals and ethics attributed to him (as recorded in the Bible) are impractical and unworkable at best; immoral and unethical at worst. In this examination I will look at his words as preserved in the four gospels, along with his works and actions. 
 
 We should assume in order to avoid foreseeable derailments that:
 
 1.) Jesus was an actual historical character, and
 
 2.) His words and deeds were faithfully preserved and recorded. 
 
 I am willing to admit here at the outset that there are some instances of benevolence and charity in Jesus' teachings, but can we agree that there are probably timeless, sound precepts in a work such as Mein Kampf also? I think the question should be, why a half-God wasn't more beneficent, why not one original thought was ever expressed by him, and why serious societal issues weren't addressed. This should be the bare minimum of someone we look upon as an ethical teacher. 
 
 With that said, and in no particular order, let's begin, piecemeal, with the Sermon on the Mount, considered his masterpiece:
 
 He begins with the Beatitudes (Blessed are the...). Is this not an endorsement of behavior? After reading it, is one not expected to strive to become whatever it is that was singled out to receive the blessing? For instance: Blessed are the meek. Should you work to become meek? Do you look for a doctor who practices meekness? Are you a practicing Christian when you seek out a meek airline pilot? Exactly how is meekness a good quality, and how does it make you a better, ethical person? Meekness is weakness, IMO. 
 
 Enough said for now.

A problem with any discussion of the ethics attributed to Jesus Christ is that he did not justify or systematize them in a treatise (like say Aristotle did - at least in the form of lecture notes). So we are left with inferences from what he is supposed to have said, written down some years after his death. This is not a completely satisfactory basis on which to get to the heart of the matter - i.e. to the core of the "thought" of anyone. So we inevitably wind up with interpretations of the sayings of Jesus as they are recorded in the New Testament.
 
 At best, we can make generalisations such as "Jesus had a philosophy of non-violence" or "Jesus believed in social justice", etc. I don't think we can be sure how a particular question of moral philosophy might have been answered by Jesus himself: we don't have enough explicit information on his ethical principles to guide us.
